Brain’s Navigation Is More Complex Than Previously Thought
Researchers uncover critical pathway that helps pancreatic cancer cells turn off immune system
description: Researchers at NYU Langone Medical Center and its Perlmutter Cancer Center have uncovered a critical pathway by which pancreatic cancer cells turn off the immune system charged with attacking them. The findings appear in a paper published online in Nature Medicine April 10.

title: Dogs Can Adopt the Perspective of Humans
Dogs Can Adopt the Perspective of Humans
Scientists develop humanized mouse model for analyzing functions of NK cells in vivo
description: Researchers affiliated with the Kawasaki INnovation Gateway at SKYFRONT, have successfully developed a humanized mouse model showing that so-called NK cells that directly attacking tumors, can survive and maintain function in vivo.

title: Patients' immune system profiles could be linked to effectiveness of cancer immunotherapy
description: Higher or lower levels of certain immune cells in cancer patients may be associated with how well they respond to immunotherapy, according to preliminary results of a study conducted by researchers at the University of Pittsburgh Cancer Institute.

title: To e-, or not to e-, the question for the exotic 'Si-III' phase of silicon
description: It would be difficult to overestimate the importance of silicon when it comes to computing, solar energy, and other technological applications. Yet there is still so much to learn about how to harness the capabilities of element number 14. The most-common form of silicon crystallizes in the same structure as diamond. New work shows that one form of silicon, Si-III, which is synthesized using a high-pressure process, is what's called a narrow band gap semiconductor.

title: To e-, or not to e-, the question for the exotic 'Si-III' phase of silicon
description: It would be difficult to overestimate the importance of silicon when it comes to computing, solar energy, and other technological applications. Yet there is still so much to learn about how to harness the capabilities of element number 14. The most-common form of silicon crystallizes in the same structure as diamond. New work shows that one form of silicon, Si-III, which is synthesized using a high-pressure process, is what's called a narrow band gap semiconductor.

title: Area of the Brain Affected by Autism Detected
In Case You Missed It
author: Andrea Marks
description: Top news from around the world

title: Physicists discover hidden aspects of electrodynamics
description: Radio waves, microwaves and even light itself are all made of electric and magnetic fields. The classical theory of electromagnetism was completed in the 1860s by James Clerk Maxwell. At the time, Maxwell's theory was revolutionary, and provided a unified framework to understand electricity, magnetism and optics. Now, new research advances knowledge of this theory.

title: Proton-nuclei smashups yield clues about 'quark gluon plasma'
description: Findings from physicists working at Europe's Large Hadron Collider are providing new insight about an exotic state of matter called the 'quark-gluon plasma' that occurs when protons and neutrons melt.

title: Diamonds coupled using quantum physics
description: Researchers at TU Wien have succeeded in coupling the specific defects in two such diamonds with one another. This is an important prerequisite for the development of new applications, such as highly sensitive sensors and switches for quantum computers.

title: Coming to a lab bench near you: Femtosecond X-ray spectroscopy
description: For the first time, researchers have captured the ephemeral electron movements in a transient state of a chemical reaction using ultrafast, tabletop X-ray spectroscopy. The researchers used femtosecond pulses of X-ray light to catch the unraveling of a ring molecule that is important in biochemical and optoelectronic processes.

title: 'Cold' great spot discovered on Jupiter
description: A Great Cold Spot comparable in scale to Jupiter's famous Great Red Spot (24,000 km west-east and 12,000 km north-south) has been found on the planet. The phenomenon, only recently observed, may have existed for thousands of years, however, this is the first direct evidence of a sustained weather system generated by polar aurorae and opens possibility on other planets.

title: NASA's MAVEN reveals Mars has metal in its atmosphere
description: Mars has electrically charged metal atoms (ions) high in its atmosphere, according to new results. The metal ions can reveal previously invisible activity in the mysterious electrically charged upper atmosphere (ionosphere) of Mars.

title: Long ago and far away, an average galaxy: 'Typical' galaxy helps astronomers study epoch of reionization
description: Using a giant galaxy cluster as a cosmic-scale lens, astronomers have discovered a galaxy from the early universe that they think is 'typical' of its time. This could help astronomers better understand the Epoch of Reionization when the first galaxies appeared.

title: Hubble spots auroras on Uranus
description: A composite image of Uranus by Voyager 2 and two different observations made by Hubble shows one for the ring and one for the auroras found around the planet.

title: Explosive material: The making of a supernova
description: Pre-supernova stars may show signs of instability for months before the big explosion, spewing material into space and creating a dense gas shell around themselves, report scientists in a new report.

title: Astrochemistry: How life may have begun in space
description: What chemical processes in space could have created the building blocks of life is being researched by chemists. In their experiments, the scientists are simulating the conditions in space to understand in detail how certain chemical reactions occur.

title: What's a knot -- and what's not -- in genomic mapping
description: Genome mapping complements DNA sequencing, offering insight into huge, intact molecules between 150,000 and 1 million base pairs in length. Obtaining measurements of such large segments is not without its challenges, but new research into the physics of nanochannel mapping may help overcome a (literal) knot in the process and advance genome mapping technology.

title: Physicists discover hidden aspects of electrodynamics
description: Radio waves, microwaves and even light itself are all made of electric and magnetic fields. The classical theory of electromagnetism was completed in the 1860s by James Clerk Maxwell. At the time, Maxwell's theory was revolutionary, and provided a unified framework to understand electricity, magnetism and optics. Now, new research advances knowledge of this theory.

title: Glowing bacteria detect buried landmines
description: Clearing landmines is dangerous work, posing risk of injury or death to personnel trying to find them. Responding to this need, researchers report a novel system combining lasers and fluorescent bacteria to remotely map the location of buried landmines and unexploded ordnance.

title: Relocation of proteins with a new nanobody tool
description: A new method by which proteins can be transported to a new location in a cell has been developed by researchers. The novel tool enables scientists to study the function of proteins depending on their position by using nanobodies. The tool can be used for a wide range of proteins and in various areas of developmental biology.

title: Laser-based dermatological procedures could be revolutionized with new technique
description: Clinicians and dermatologists have seen a rise in demand for minimally invasive laser-based treatments, including tattoo removal. However, it is difficult for the laser light to be perfectly and selectively absorbed by only the targeted birthmark or tattoo. Now, researchers have developed instruments that transmit laser light into the tissue through direct contact. The techniques developed will reduce safety concerns in laser dermatology by improving laser transmission.

title: Medically monitoring premature babies with cameras
description: Researchers have developed a contactless and wireless camera system to continuously monitor the vital signs of premature babies. This system could replace skin sensors, which cause false alarms nearly 90 percent of the time.

title: Graphene, electricity used to change stem cells for nerve regrowth
description: Scientists are combining their expertise to change stem cells for nerve regrowth.

title: Proton-nuclei smashups yield clues about 'quark gluon plasma'
description: Findings from physicists working at Europe's Large Hadron Collider are providing new insight about an exotic state of matter called the 'quark-gluon plasma' that occurs when protons and neutrons melt.

title: Fast capture of cancer markers will aid in diagnosis, treatment
description: A nanoscale product of human cells that was once considered junk is now known to play an important role in intercellular communication and in many disease processes, including cancer metastasis. Researchers have developed nanoprobes to rapidly isolate these rare markers, called extracellular vesicles (EVs), for potential development of precision cancer diagnoses and personalized anticancer treatments.

title: Diamonds coupled using quantum physics
description: Researchers at TU Wien have succeeded in coupling the specific defects in two such diamonds with one another. This is an important prerequisite for the development of new applications, such as highly sensitive sensors and switches for quantum computers.

title: Controlling electron spin for efficient water splitting
description: Water is made of oxygen and hydrogen, and splitting water molecules to produce hydrogen for fuel is a promising path for alternative energy. One of the main obstacles to making hydrogen production a reality is that current methods of water splitting result in hydrogen peroxide also being formed. Now researchers have succeeded in almost fully suppressing the production of hydrogen peroxide by controlling the spin of electrons in the reaction. The efficient production of hydrogen paves the way toward the use of solar energy to split water.

title: Inkjet process to print flexible touchscreens cost-efficiently
description: Flexible smart phones are desirable for a lot of users. Up to now the displays of the innumerable phones and pods are rigid and do not yield to the anatomical forms adopted by the people carrying them. By now it is no longer any secret that the big players in the industry are working on flexible displays. New research shows how they might become reality in the near future.

title: New radar scanner tests wind turbine blades for defects
description: Thanks to the innovative radar scanner, defects in the material composition of the wind turbine blades can now be detected with far greater accuracy and visualized in a cross-sectional view, thereby saving costs in production and operation.

title: Astrochemistry: How life may have begun in space
description: What chemical processes in space could have created the building blocks of life is being researched by chemists. In their experiments, the scientists are simulating the conditions in space to understand in detail how certain chemical reactions occur.

title: Ultra-thin multilayer film for next-generation data storage and processing
description: Scientists have invented a novel ultra-thin multilayer film which could harness the properties of tiny magnetic whirls, known as skyrmions, as information carriers for storing and processing data on magnetic media.

title: Thin film transistors printed entirely with layered materials
description: Printed transistors have now been fabricated consisting entirely of layered materials. The team’s findings have the potential to cheaply print a range of electronic devices from solar cells to LEDs with applications from interactive smart food and drug labels to next-generation banknote security and e-passports.

title: Novel catalyst to convert carbon dioxide invented
description: A new catalyst that can efficiently convert carbon dioxide (CO2) to carbon monoxide (CO) has been invented by scientists. This soon-to-be patented invention enables the sustainable utilization of CO2, a potent greenhouse gas linked to climate change. If successful on a larger scale, this invention could provide a practical way for converting CO2 to useful chemicals.

title: Coming to a lab bench near you: Femtosecond X-ray spectroscopy
description: For the first time, researchers have captured the ephemeral electron movements in a transient state of a chemical reaction using ultrafast, tabletop X-ray spectroscopy. The researchers used femtosecond pulses of X-ray light to catch the unraveling of a ring molecule that is important in biochemical and optoelectronic processes.

title: Record new renewable power capacity added worldwide at lower cost
description: As clean technology costs continue to fall, the world added record levels of renewable energy capacity in 2016, at an investment level 23 percent lower than 2015, new UN-backed research shows.

title: Graphene, electricity used to change stem cells for nerve regrowth
description: Scientists are combining their expertise to change stem cells for nerve regrowth.

title: Ultra-thin multilayer film for next-generation data storage and processing
description: Scientists have invented a novel ultra-thin multilayer film which could harness the properties of tiny magnetic whirls, known as skyrmions, as information carriers for storing and processing data on magnetic media.

title: Did you catch that? Robot's speed of light communication could protect you from danger
description: If you were monitoring a security camera and saw someone set down a backpack and walk away, you might pay special attention -- especially if you had been alerted to watch that particular person. According to researchers, this might be a job robots could do better than humans, by communicating at the speed of light and sharing images.

title: Glowing bacteria detect buried landmines

title: Clock Gene Mutation Leads to “Night Owl” Behavior
author: Diana Kwon
description: Scientists identify a mutation in the CRY1 gene in people with abnormal sleeping patterns.

title: FDA OKs Marketing of DTC Genetic Health-Risk Tests
author: Diana Kwon
description: 23andMe customers can now receive information about genetic risk for diseases including Parkinson’s and celiac.

title: Cephalopod Genomes Contain Thousands of Conserved RNA Editing Sites
author: Abby Olena
description: Octopus, cuttlefish, and squid extensively edit messenger RNAs in an evolutionarily conserved process.

title: Cross-Sample Sequencing Contamination Galore
author: Ruth Williams
description: Scientists conducting a large-scale, comparative transcriptomics project have inadvertently highlighted widespread contamination in sequencing data.

title: Record-Setting Corn Grows 45 Feet Tal
author: Jef Akst
description: A plant breeder succeeds in growing a huge maize plant thanks to a known mutation and a few environmental tricks.

title: Unveiling nonlocal correlations in natural systems
description: Nonlocal correlations are a quantum phenomenon that constitute a stronger form of correlations than quantum entanglement, new research shows. Now researchers have developed a new method to show that the low energy states of some physical spin Hamiltonians can exhibit these nonlocal correlations.

title: Research group works toward devising topological superconductor
description: A new topological superconductor made from an ultrathin transition metal dichalcogenide is a step toward quantum computing, suggests a new research report.

title: First 'image' of a dark matter web that connects galaxies
description: Researchers have been able to capture the first composite image of a dark matter bridge that connects galaxies together.

title: Art of paper-cutting inspires self-charging paper device
description: Despite the many advances in portable electronic devices, one thing remains constant: the need to plug them into a wall socket to recharge. Now researchers have developed a light-weight, paper-based device inspired by the Chinese and Japanese arts of paper-cutting that can harvest and store energy from body movements.

title: Tunable electric eyeglasses bend to the will of the wearer
description: Engineers have developed glasses with liquid-based lenses that “flex” to refocus on whatever the wearer is viewing.

title: 3-D printing helps surgeons sharpen their craft
description: Surgical training is one more way that researchers are using 3-D printing to advance the quality of care. 3-D printed simulations of lifelike body parts allow surgeons in training the opportunity to practice complex surgeries before assisting with the real thing.

title: Legendary Climate Scientist Likes a GOP Proposal on Global Warming
author: Annie Sneed
description: James Hansen, the “father of climate change awareness,” wants the same carbon fee–and-dividend strategy proposed by Republicans

title: Hematologist-oncologist to lead bone marrow transplantation program for treating blood-borne cancers
description: Hematologist-oncologist Ahmad Samer Al-Homsi MD, MBA, will lead a new bone marrow transplantation program at NYU Langone's Perlmutter Cancer Center for treating blood-borne cancers, including leukemia, lymphoma and multiple myeloma, and potentially utilize transplantation as an adjunct to immunotherapy for solid tumors.

title: Researchers solve medical mystery through genetics
description: Researchers have identified the genetic mutation responsible for one patient's serious health problems, finally solving a medical mystery that has endured for over 30 years.

title: Activation of specific protein could lead to acute lymphoblastic leukemia, study reveals
description: The discovery of a protein signature that is highly predictive of leukemia could lead to novel treatments of the leading childhood cancer, according to new study showing that competition among certain proteins causes an imbalance that leads to leukemia.

title: Americans Used a Lot Less Coal in 2016
author: Bobby Magill and Climate Central
description: U.S. coal use has steadily declined since it peaked a decade ago

title: Human Vaccines Project, VUMC and Illumina team up to decipher genetic underpinnings of immune system
description: The Human Vaccines Project and Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC) today announced that they joined forces with Illumina, Inc., to decipher the human immunome, the genetic underpinnings of the immune system.

title: The Arctic Ocean Is Becoming More Like the Atlantic Ocean
author: Brian Kahn and Climate Central
description: The changes are already visible in the region, which has had largely ice-free summers since 2011

title: Legendary Climate Scientist Likes a GOP Proposal on Global Warming
author: Annie Sneed
description: James Hansen, the “father of climate change awareness,” wants the same carbon fee–and-dividend strategy proposed by Republicans

title: Politicians Shouldn't Troll through Scientists' E-Mails
author: Kevin Cowtan and Zeke Hausfather
description: They are useless in evaluating whether research results are correct

title: Salk Institute receives additional $3 million Glenn Foundation gift to continue aging research
description: The Salk Institute has received a $3 million gift from the Glenn Foundation for Medical Research for the second time in 4 years, enabling the Institute to continue investigating the biology of normal human aging and age-related diseases.

title: Patients with inducible urticaria can benefit from treatment with asthma drug
description: Patients who develop itchy wheals in response to cold or friction benefit from treatment with omalizumab, a drug normally used to treat asthma.

title: TSRI scientists find new way to make cell population resistant to HIV
description: Scientists at The Scripps Research Institute have found a way to tether HIV-fighting antibodies to immune cells, creating a cell population resistant to the virus.

title: A Last-Ditch Attempt to Save the World's Most Endangered Porpoise
author: Henry Nicholls and Nature magazine
description: Officials approved a plan to round up the last 30 vaquitas into protective “sea pens”

title: New transgenic mouse could help monitor potential dangers of emerging influenza viruses
description: Researchers in Germany have developed a transgenic mouse that could help scientists identify new influenza virus strains with the potential to cause a global pandemic.

title: China's Xi Outshines Trump as the World's Future Energy Leader
author: David Biello
description: Failure by the two presidents to discuss climate change leaves China ahead, based on actions if not words

title: Court Upholds California's Cap-and-Trade Program
author: Debra Kahn and E&E News
description: The state’s landmark system for curbing carbon emissions can continue through at least 2020

title: Immunologists discover how rescue proteins delay ‘executioner’ machinery that kills damaged cells
description: A research team led by St. Jude Children's Research Hospital immunologists has discovered how a set of proteins delays the "executioner" machinery that kills damaged or infected cells in a process called necroptosis.

title: Antibody treatment protects non-human primates against deadly Marburg and Ravn viruses
description: An antibody treatment successfully protected nonhuman primates against the deadly Marburg and Ravn viruses even when given five days after becoming infected, according to the latest findings of a collaborative team from The University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston, Mapp Biopharmaceutical Inc., and Vanderbilt University. The findings are now available in Science Translational Medicine.

title: Researchers map gene activity to reveal how the liver performs different functions
description: If you get up in the morning feeling energetic and clearheaded, you can thank your liver for manufacturing glucose before breakfast time. Among a host of other vital functions, it also clears our body of toxins and produces most of the carrier proteins in our blood.

title: TSRI professor receives $4.8 million grant to advance potential HIV vaccine research
description: Professor Michael Farzan, co-chair of the Department of Immunology and Microbiology on the Florida campus of The Scripps Research Institute has received $4.8 million in funding through a 2017 Avant-Garde Award for HIV/AIDS research from the National Institutes of Health's National Institute on Drug Abuse.

title: New research sheds light on movement of white blood cells to sites of infection
description: One of the mysteries of the living body is the movement of cells - not just in the blood, but through cellular and other barriers.

title: Salk scientists discover chemical cocktail that enables stem cells to generate tissues
description: When scientists talk about laboratory stem cells being totipotent or pluripotent, they mean that the cells have the potential, like an embryo, to develop into any type of tissue in the body.

title: How to color a lizard: From biology to mathematics
description: Skin color patterns in animals arise from microscopic interactions among colored cells that obey equations, say investigators. Researchers report that a lizard acquires its adult skin color by changing the color of individual skin scales. The work shows that the 3-D geometry of the lizard's skin scales causes the Turing mechanism to transform into the von Neumann computing system.

title: Meet 'DeeDee,' a distant, dim member of our solar system
description: Using the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), astronomers have revealed extraordinary details about a recently discovered far-flung member of our solar system, the planetary body 2014 UZ224, more informally known as DeeDee.

title: Collisions generate gas in debris disks
description: By examining the atomic carbon line from two young star systems -- 49 Ceti and Beta Pictoris -- researchers had found atomic carbon in the disk, the first time this observation has been made at sub-millimeter wavelength, hinting that the gas in debris disks is not primordial, but rather is generated from some process of collisions taking place in the debris disk.

title: New 3-D printing method creates shape-shifting objects
description: A new 3-D printing method has been developed to create objects that can permanently transform into a range of different shapes in response to heat.

title: Nanoparticle research tested in locusts focuses on new drug-delivery method
description: A team of engineers has combined nanoparticles, aerosol science and locusts in new proof-of-concept research that could someday vastly improve drug delivery to the brain, making it as simple as a sniff.

title: Algal residue: Alternative carbon resource for pharmaceuticals and polyesters
description: Algal residue, the leftover material after extracting oil from algae for biofuel, can be used to produce key industrial chemicals, researchers have determined.

title: Surprisingly long lifetime of high adhesion property of plasma-treated Polytetrafluoroethylene
description: Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), or Telfon® as it is better known, is used in a variety of daily products, from cookware to carpets, because of its non-sticky property. However, this very same non-stickiness has limited its application to other fields including medicine. Scientists have reported how heat-assisted plasma treatment can modify PTFE to solve this problem.

title: More objective than human hearing
description: In industrial production, the testing of machines and products by means of acoustic signals still takes a niche role. Researchers are exhibiting a 'cognitive system' that detects erroneous sounds more objectively than the human ear. The technology has successfully passed the initial practical tests and there detected up to 99 percent of the errors.

title: Shoe-string theory: Science shows why shoelaces come untied
description: A new study shows why your shoelaces may keep coming untied. A better understanding of knot mechanics is needed for sharper insight into how knotted structures fail under a variety of forces.

title: Microprocessors based on a layer of just three atoms
description: Microprocessors based on atomically thin materials hold the promise of the evolution of traditional processors as well as new applications in the field of flexible electronics. Now, a team has made a breakthrough in this field as part of an ongoing research project.

title: Surprisingly long lifetime of high adhesion property of plasma-treated Polytetrafluoroethylene
description: Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), or Telfon® as it is better known, is used in a variety of daily products, from cookware to carpets, because of its non-sticky property. However, this very same non-stickiness has limited its application to other fields including medicine. Scientists have reported how heat-assisted plasma treatment can modify PTFE to solve this problem.

Researchers are exhibiting a 'cognitive system' that detects erroneous sounds more objectively than the human ear. The technology has successfully passed the initial practical tests and there detected up to 99 percent of the errors.

title: CRISPR Corrects Duchenne-Causing Mutations
author: Anna Azvolinsky
description: Using CRISPR-Cpf1 gene editing, researchers have fixed mutations that cause a form of muscular dystrophy in cultured human cardiomyocytes and a mouse model.

title: Whales Keep Carbon out of the Atmosphere
author: Kavya Balaraman and E&E News
description: If conservation efforts pay off, whales could help islands meet their emissions reductions

title: Is the U.S. Ready for Future Disease Threats?
author: Dina Fine Maron
description: The CDC lacks the authority to direct funding in response to emergencies and outbreaks

title: Shredded Stars Offer New View of Supermassive Black Holes
author: S. Bradley Cenko and Neil Gehrels
description: New techniques reveal how supermassive black holes shred entire stars

title: A rash of overdoses in West Virginia made national news. This is the story of the man who caused it
author: Andrew Joseph

title: ‘Everybody knows somebody’: This state is a laboratory for the future of Alzheimer’s in America
Biotech has a fake news problem. Now, the SEC is cracking down
author: Damian Garde

title: Reject the pseudoscience of homeopathy
Banning trans fats in New York prevented thousands of heart attacks, study finds
author: Leah Samuel

title: 18 must-follow Twitter accounts about health and medicine
author: Helen Branswell

title: An outrageous hospital charge: I paid $710 for an hour of babysitting
Mighty morphed brain cells cure Parkinson’s in mice, but human trials still far off
author: Sharon Begley

title: Computer game helps scientists understand animal camouflage
description: Online computer games played by more than 30,000 people have helped scientists understand animal camouflage and color vision.

title: California's Droughts and Deluges Traced to Atmospheric Waves
author: John Fialka and ClimateWire
description: The wavelike patterns are caused by the Earth's rotation, and can have strong effects on local weather

title: US Regulators Test Organs-on-Chips for Food-Safety Monitoring
author: Sara Reardon and Nature magazine
description: The goal is to compare these engineered livers to animal models, with an eye towards replacing animal testing

title: Energetic 2-Ball Bounces
author: Science Buddies and Sabine de Brabandere
description: A bouncing project from Science Buddies

title: Michigan’s ‘stealth move’ to increase vaccination rates
‘We didn’t expect this’: A historic yellow fever outbreak spreads in Brazil
‘Neuron-Reading’ Nanowires Could Accelerate Development of Drugs for Neurological Diseases
Early School Start Times Pit Teens in Conflict Between Biology and Society
CRISPR Corrects Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
The Brain Cells That Keep Mice Active
Looking ahead to the future of computer-driven cars
description: Amnon Shashua PhD ’93, co-founder of Mobileye, discusses challenges associated with autonomous vehicles in MIT visit.
author: Julie Pryor | McGovern Institute for Brain Research

title: New insights into 'ocean worlds' in our solar system
description: Two veteran NASA missions are providing new details about icy, ocean-bearing moons of Jupiter and Saturn, further heightening the scientific interest of these and other "ocean worlds" in our solar system and beyond. Scientists announce that a form of chemical energy that life can feed on appears to exist on Saturn's moon Enceladus, and researchers also report additional evidence of plumes erupting from Jupiter's moon Europa.

title: New infrared-emitting device could allow energy harvesting from waste heat
description: A new reconfigurable device that emits patterns of thermal infrared light in a fully controllable manner could one day make it possible to collect waste heat at infrared wavelengths and turn it into usable energy.

title: Device pulls water from dry air, powered only by the sun
description: While it's easy to condense water from humid air, machines that harvest water from drier air require energy. Researchers have created the first water harvester that uses only ambient sunlight. The key component is an extremely porous material called a metal-organic framework that absorbs 20 percent of its weight in water from low-humidity air. Sunlight heats the MOF, releasing the water vapor, which condenses to produce liters of water per day.

title: Device pulls water from dry air, powered only by the sun
description: While it's easy to condense water from humid air, machines that harvest water from drier air require energy. Researchers have created the first water harvester that uses only ambient sunlight. The key component is an extremely porous material called a metal-organic framework that absorbs 20 percent of its weight in water from low-humidity air. Sunlight heats the MOF, releasing the water vapor, which condenses to produce liters of water per day.

title: New infrared-emitting device could allow energy harvesting from waste heat
description: A new reconfigurable device that emits patterns of thermal infrared light in a fully controllable manner could one day make it possible to collect waste heat at infrared wavelengths and turn it into usable energy.

title: Method improves semiconductor fiber optics, paves way for developing devices
description: A new method to improve semiconductor fiber optics may lead to a material structure that might one day revolutionize the global transmission of data, according to an interdisciplinary team of researchers.

title: Bistatic laser monitor sees through fire
description: The creation of new materials is often accompanied with powerful illumination. Scientists are designing an advanced bistatic laser monitor that enables observing high-speed processes hidden by background lighting, e.g. at welding. The newly developed two-laser monitor makes it possible to obtain better images and even to observe X-ray processes from a safe distance.

title: How some battery materials expand without cracking
description: New findings show some phosphate-based battery materials can change from crystalline to glassy while in use, possibly opening new avenues for design of batteries.

title: 'Neuron-reading' nanowires could accelerate development of drugs for neurological diseases
description: Engineers have developed nanowires that can record the electrical activity of neurons in fine detail. The new nanowire technology could one day serve as a platform to screen drugs for neurological diseases and could enable researchers to better understand how single cells communicate in large neuronal networks.

title: Antarctica's Sleeping Ice Giant Could Wake Soon
author: Jane Qiu and Nature magazine
description: The massive East Antarctic Ice Sheet looks stable from above—but it’s a dangerously different story below

title: Researchers resolve key question on titanium oxide, water interactions
description: When water comes in for a landing on the common catalyst titanium oxide, it splits into hydroxyls just under half the time. Water's oxygen and hydrogen atoms shift back and forth between existing as water or hydroxyls, and water has the slightest advantage, like the score in a highly competitive tennis game.

title: Pharmalot, Pharmalittle: Apple working in secret on the ‘holy grail’ for treating diabetes
author: Meghana Keshavan

author: Damian Garde

author: Ed Silverman

author: Meghana Keshavan

author: Andrew Joseph

author: Sheila Kaplan

title: To boost diversity in clinical trials, researchers seek out allies — starting with black pastors
author: Max Blau

title: The story behind PhRMA’s multimillion-dollar rebranding effort
author: Damian Garde

title: New method for 3-D printing extraterrestrial materials
description: 3-D printing with lunar and Martian dust-based inks presents a new, sustainable method for extraterrestrial manufacturing of soft and hard structures and objects.

title: Milky Way’s ionized hydrogen brought into focus
description: Building on efforts to tease out a new and mostly hidden feature of our galaxy, astronomers have developed WHAM, a spectrometer capable of detecting the faint, diffuse light emanating from the space between the stars.

title: 3D-printed patch can help mend a 'broken' heart
description: A revolutionary 3D-bioprinted patch has been created that can help heal scarred heart tissue after a heart attack. The discovery is a major step forward in treating patients with tissue damage after a heart attack.

title: Researchers design coatings to prevent pipeline clogging
description: A new coating could prevent methane clathrate clogs and blowouts in oil pipelines, potentially stopping a buildup of hydrate ices that slow or block oil and gas flow.

title: Key question on titanium oxide, water interactions resolved
description: When water comes in for a landing on the common catalyst titanium oxide, it splits into hydroxyls just under half the time. Water's oxygen and hydrogen atoms shift back and forth between existing as water or hydroxyls, and water has the slightest advantage, like the score in a highly competitive tennis game.

title: New method for 3-D printing extraterrestrial materials
description: 3-D printing with lunar and Martian dust-based inks presents a new, sustainable method for extraterrestrial manufacturing of soft and hard structures and objects.

title: Bubble group dancing
description: A new bubbling mechanism may exist within the realm of physics, researchers have discovered. They made this surprising finding while studying the bubbling phenomena in submerged gas-liquid jets in microchannels. The phenomenon occurred in an immersion lithography machine they had developed, causing vibrations that were damaging exposure quality.

title: Triple treatment for heat-exchangers: New nano-coatings have an anti-adhesive, anti-corrosive and antimicrobial effect
description: When processing milk and juice, the food industry is using heat exchangers in numerous steps throughout the process. To have no risk to the consumers, heat exchangers have to be free from microbes. Especially in the numerous grooves and recesses of the heat exchanger, persistent biofilms can remain stuck. As a result, heat exchangers must be cleaned at regular intervals using aggressive chemicals. These increase the sensitivity for corrosion, especially if mild steel is used as heat exchanger material.

title: Silver circuits on foil allow curved touchscreens
description: Scientists have developed a so called 'photochemical metallization.'

title: 3D-printed patch can help mend a 'broken' heart
description: A revolutionary 3D-bioprinted patch has been created that can help heal scarred heart tissue after a heart attack. The discovery is a major step forward in treating patients with tissue damage after a heart attack.

title: New method for 3-D printing extraterrestrial materials
description: 3-D printing with lunar and Martian dust-based inks presents a new, sustainable method for extraterrestrial manufacturing of soft and hard structures and objects.

title: Explained: Neural networks
description: Ballyhooed artificial-intelligence technique known as “deep learning” revives 70-year-old idea.
author: Larry Hardesty | MIT News Office

title: Shoelace Study Untangles a Knotty Problem
author: Karen Hopkin
description: Researchers have trotted out data that show a combination of whipping and stomping forces is what causes laces to unravel without warning. Karen Hopkin reports.

title: Unraveling Why Shoelace Knots Fail
author: Erin Ross and Nature magazine
description: A better understanding of this pedestrian problem could lead to improved surgeons’ knots and fibers

Oxytocin Being Tested For PTSD and Alcohol Abuse

Cause of Fatal Childhood Disorder Revealed
The March for Science could save lives
description: When Ebola began to spread in West Africa in December 2013, it was invisible. A 2-year-old who had been playing near a bat-filled tree in southeastern Guinea died, apparently the first victim, but it took months for health workers to detect and report the spread of a disease with a high mortality. Soon it raged across Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, sickening 28,000 people and killing 11,000. Scientists have now tracked the pathways of the virus in once-unimaginable detail, providing important lessons for preventing another outbreak. This is a terrific example of science at work for society, and it shows why this weekend’s March for Science is relevant.

title: The March for Science: Why Some Are Going, and Some Will Sit Out
description: The March for Science on April 22 may or may not accomplish the goals set out by its organizers. But it has required many people who work in a variety of scientific fields — as well as Americans who are passionate about science — to grapple with the proper role of science in our civic life.

title: Nanoimprinted hyperlens array: Paving the way for practical super-resolution imaging
description: Research has demonstrated a scalable and reliable fabrication process of a large scale hyperlens device based on direct pattern transfer techniques. The research team's new cost-effective fabrication method can be used to proliferate practical far-field and real-time super-resolution imaging devices that can be widely used in optics, biology, medical science, nanotechnology, and other related interdisciplinary fields.

title: Quantum mechanics is complex enough, for now...
description: Physicists have searched for deviations from standard quantum mechanics, testing whether quantum mechanics requires a more complex set of mathematical rules. To do so a research team designed a new photonic experiment using exotic metamaterials. Their experiment supports standard quantum mechanics and allows the scientists to place bounds on alternative quantum theories. The results could help to guide theoretical work in a search for a more general version of quantum mechanics.

title: New quantum liquid crystals may play role in future of computers
description: The first 3-D quantum liquid crystals may have applications in quantum computing, report scientists. Liquid crystals fall somewhere in between a liquid and a solid: they are made up of molecules that flow around freely as if they were a liquid but are all oriented in the same direction, as in a solid. Liquid crystals can be found in nature, such as in biological cell membranes. Alternatively, they can be made artificially -- such as those found in the liquid crystal displays commonly used in watches, smartphones, televisions, and other items that have display screens.

title: Engineering technique is damaging materials research reveals
description: A technique that revolutionized scientists' ability to manipulate and study minuscule materials, may have dramatic unintended consequences -- altering their structural identity, new research reveals.

title: Novel semiconductor nanofiber with superb charge conductivity developed
description: A novel technology that embeds highly conductive nanostructure into semi-conductor nanofiber has now been developed by researchers. The novel composite so produced has superb charge conductivity, and can therefore be widely applied, especially in environmental arena.

title: 'Gamers' method creates unique 4-D molecular spectral maps
description: Researchers have created a new method to extract the static and dynamic structure of complex chemical systems. In this context, 'structure' doesn't just mean the 3-D arrangement of atoms that make up a molecule, but rather time-dependent quantum-mechanical degrees of freedom that dictate the optical, chemical and physical properties of the system.

title: Creating time crystals
description: Researchers created a previously-only-theoretical time crystal using a small piece of diamond embedded with millions of atomic-scale impurities known as nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers. They then used microwave pulses to 'kick' the system out of equilibrium, causing the NV center's spins to flip at precisely-timed intervals.

title: Method to control light propagation in waveguides invented
description: Engineers have invented a method to control light propagating in confined pathways, or waveguides, with high efficiency by using nano-antennas. They built photonic integrated devices that had record-small footprints and were also able to maintain optimal performance over an unprecedented broad wavelength range. The method could lead to faster, more powerful, and more efficient optical chips, which in turn could transform optical communications and optical signal processing.

title: Physicists create 'negative mass'
description: Physicists have created a fluid with negative mass, which is exactly what it sounds like. Push it, and unlike every physical object in the world we know, it doesn't accelerate in the direction it was pushed. It accelerates backwards.

title: Computers create recipe for two new magnetic materials
description: Material scientists have predicted and built two new magnetic materials, atom-by-atom, using high-throughput computational models. The success marks a new era for the large-scale design of new magnetic materials at unprecedented speed.

title: A quantum low pass for photons
description: Physicists have observed a novel quantum effect that limits the number of emitted photons, outlines a new report.

title: New measurements suggest ‘antineutrino anomaly’ fueled by modeling error
description: Results from a new study could explain a mismatch between predictions and recent measurements of ghostly particles streaming from nuclear reactors -- the so-called “reactor antineutrino anomaly” that has puzzled physicists since 2011.

title: Faster biosensor for healthcare now developed
description: A new technology has been designed that is 20 times faster than the existing biosensors using micromagnetic pattern of spider web. The technology can be used for early diagnosis and recurrence diagnosis of diseases such as cancer.

title: BP oil spill did $17.2 billion in damage to natural resources, scientists find
description: The 2010 BP Deepwater Horizon oil spill did $17.2 billion in damage to the natural resources in the Gulf of Mexico, a team of scientists recently found after a six-year study of the impact of the largest oil spill in US history.

title: By listening to optical 'noise,' researchers discover new way to track hidden objects
description: Researchers have developed a new solution to tracking objects hidden behind scattering media by analyzing the fluctuations in optical 'noise' created by their movement. The approach could help fill in the gaps where LIDAR and other line-of-sight based methods fall short, advancing remote sensing and biomedical applications.

title: New microscopy method breaks color barrier of optical imaging
description: A significant step has been made toward breaking the so-called 'color barrier' of light microscopy for biological systems, allowing for much more comprehensive, system-wide labeling and imaging of a greater number of biomolecules in living cells and tissues than is currently attainable. The advancement has the potential for many future applications, including helping to guide the development of therapies to treat and cure disease.

title: Scientific advance for cool clothing: Temperature-wise, that is
description: A low-cost plastic material has now been developed that could become the basis for clothing that cools the wearer, reducing the need for energy-consuming air conditioning.

title: Graphene 'copy machine' may produce cheap semiconductor wafers
description: A new technique may vastly reduce the overall cost of wafer technology and enable devices made from more exotic, higher-performing semiconductor materials than conventional silicon. The new method uses graphene -- single-atom-thin sheets of graphite -- as a sort of 'copy machine' to transfer intricate crystalline patterns from an underlying semiconductor wafer to a top layer of identical material.

title: New method to create the next fuel-efficient renewable energy developed
description: The fossil fuel fight goes on for scientists as they develop a new method for creating reversible hydrogen storage based on methanol, with no carbon emissions, in the last major paper co-authored by USC's first Nobel laureate, the late George Olah.

title: Making batteries from waste glass bottles
description: Researchers have used waste glass bottles and a low-cost chemical process to create nanosilicon anodes for high-performance lithium-ion batteries. The batteries will extend the range of electric vehicles and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles, and provide more power with fewer charges to personal electronics like cell phones and laptops.

title: Graphene and gold make a better brain probe
description: Scientists have created more flexible neural electrodes that minimize tissue damage and still transmit clear brain signals.

title: Nanoparticles remain unpredictable
description: The way that nanoparticles behave in the environment is extremely complex. There is currently a lack of systematic experimental data to help understand them comprehensively, as environmental scientists have shown in a large overview study. A more standardized approach would help to advance the research field.

title: Shale gas threat to forests can be eased by consolidating infrastructure
description: Fragmentation of ecologically important core forests within the northern Appalachians -- driven by pipeline and access road construction -- is the major threat posed by shale-gas development, according to researchers, who recommend a change in infrastructure-siting policies to head off loss of this critical habitat.

title: Making oil from algae: Towards more efficient biofuels
description: The mechanism behind oil synthesis within microalgae cells has now been revealed by a research team. This discovery could contribute to the development of biofuels, they say.

title: Robotic cheetah created
description: Engineers have developed a prototype cheetah robot. They have constructed a scaled-down robotic version of the fastest land animal in the world, with a view to replicating its movements. Relatively speaking, the robot moves using only about fifteen percent more energy than a real cheetah.

title: Adjusting solar panel angles a few times a year makes them more efficient
description: With Earth Day approaching, new research could help people save more energy, regardless of location, if they adjust the angles of solar panels four to five times a year, based on the seasons.

title: Better living through pressure: Functional nanomaterials made easy
description: Using pressure instead of chemicals, nanoparticles have been fabricated into nanowire arrays similar to those that underlie touch-screens for phones, computers, TVs, and sensors. The pressure process takes nanoseconds instead of the hours required by industry's current chemical means, say investigators.

title: New dye allows super-imaging of cells
description: A new dye might allow researchers to view natural processes in extremely small components of living cells over a prolonged period of time, a previously unattainable feat.

title: IVs: Catching those nasty, leaky drips
description: A new adhesive sensor can save patients the discomfort and pain resulting from leaky intravenous drips, say developers of the new technology.

title: Rapid screening machine can read and separate protein sequences
description: The structural properties of proteins that could eventually become important materials for manufacturing and medicine are revealed by a novel optical technique that works rapidly to sort through amino acid sequences even inside living bacteria, according to a team of engineers.

title: Harnessing heat to power computers
description: Heat is commonly regarded as computing's mortal enemy. Two researchers, however, flipped the question of how to keep computers cool to how to use heat as an alternative energy source.

title: Scientists combine a peptide with a nano cancer drug formulation to improve treatment effectiveness and prevent metastasis in pancreatic cancer
description: Scientists have unlocked an important mechanism that allows chemotherapy-carrying nanoparticles—extremely small objects between 1 and 100 nanometers (a billionth of a meter)—to directly access pancreatic cancer tumors, thereby improving the ability to kill cancer cells and hence leading to more effective treatment outcome of the disease. The researchers also confirmed the key role of a peptide (an extremely small protein) in regulating vascular access of the nanoparticle to the cancer site.

title: New battery coating could improve smart phones and electric vehicles
description: High performing lithium-ion batteries are a key component of laptops, smart phones, and electric vehicles. Currently, the anodes, or negative charged side of lithium ion batteries, are generally made with graphite or other carbon-based materials. Now a new discovery may help unravel a 40-year mystery and could greatly improve battery performance in electronic devices and electric vehicles

title: High-resolution imaging with conventional microscopes
description: Researchers have developed a way to make extremely high-resolution images of tissue samples, at a fraction of the cost of other techniques with similar resolution. Known as iterative expansion microscopy, relies on expanding tissue repeatedly, before imaging it with a conventional light microscope.

title: Tweaking a molecule's structure can send it down a different path to crystallization
description: Silky chocolate, a better medical drug, or solar panels all require the same thing: just the right crystals making up the material. Now, scientists trying to understand the paths crystals take as they form have been able to influence that path by modifying the starting ingredient.

title: Nano-SPEARs gently measure electrical signals in small animals
description: Microscopic probes simplify the process of measuring electrical activity in the cells of small living animals. The technique could revolutionize data-gathering for disease characterization and drug interactions.

title: Twist and shine: Development of a new photoluminescent sensor material
description: Stress sensors are important tools when it comes to evaluating the robustness of a material facing strong mechanical forces. Researchers have just published an article reporting a new kind of sensor molecules that brightens up when the material they are incorporated into comes under heavy mechanical stress.

title: Mechanism behind the electric charges generated by photosynthesis
description: Photosynthesis requires a mechanism to produce large amounts of chemical energy without losing the oxidative power needed to break down water. A research team has clarified part of this mechanism, marking another step towards the potential development of artificial photosynthesis.

title: SAVI camera ditches long lens for distant images
description: A new camera platform has been introduced that uses laser 'speckle' patterns to capture high-resolution images from a distance without telescopic lenses.

title: Nuclease-resistant hybrid nanoflowers
description: An eco-friendly method to synthesize DNA-copper nanoflowers with high load efficiencies, low cytotoxicity, and strong resistance against nucleases has been developed by researchers.

title: Migratory Eels Use Magnetoreception
author: Kerry Grens
description: In laboratory experiments that simulated oceanic conditions, the fish responded to magnetic fields, a sensory input that may aid migration.

title: Image of the Day: Fungal Forms
author: The Scientist Staff
description: By sequencing and analyzing the genomes of more than 20 species of Penicillium fungi, researches uncovered genes encoding for numerous bioactive compounds, including antibiotics.

title: Opinion: More Biomarkers Needed for Cancer Immunotherapy
author: David Fabrizio
description: Measuring PD-L1 levels was a great start. Now we need to quantify more protein biomarkers, assess the tumor mutational landscape, and examine immune cell signatures, too.

title: Drones collect measurements from a volcanic plume at Volcán de Fuego, Guatemala
description: A team of volcanologists and engineers have collected measurements from directly within volcanic clouds, together with visual and thermal images of inaccessible volcano peaks.

title: Better than nature: Artificial biofilm increases energy production in microbial fuel cells
description: Microbial fuel cells exploit the metabolism of bacteria in order to generate electricity. A new type of biofilm could soon make this relatively young technology considerably more effective, more stable, and easier to use. A research team has succeeded in producing a material that is far better suited for energy production in fuel cells than natural biofilms.

title: Searching for ET: Breakthrough Listen initiative publishes initial results
description: Breakthrough Listen -- the initiative to find signs of intelligent life in the universe -- has released its 11 events ranked highest for significance as well as summary data analysis results. It is considered unlikely that any of these signals originate from artificial extraterrestrial sources, but the search continues.

title: Landslides on Ceres reflect hidden ice
description: Massive landslides, similar to those found on Earth, are occurring on the asteroid Ceres. That's according to a new study adding to the growing evidence that Ceres retains a significant amount of water ice.

title: Living with a star: NASA and partners survey space weather science
description: Storms from the sun can affect our power grids, railway systems and underground pipelines. Now scientists and engineers from NASA have assessed the state of science surrounding space weather.

title: Hubble sees starbursts in Virgo
description: Starburst galaxies contain regions where stars are forming at such a breakneck rate that the galaxy is eating up its gas supply faster than it can be replenished.

title: Can we see a singularity, the most extreme object in the universe?
description: Scientists have found new ways to detect a bare or naked singularity, the most extreme object in the universe. This finding has possible astrophysical implications.

title: Gaming helps personalized therapy level up
description: Using game features in non-game contexts, computers can learn to build personalized mental- and physical-therapy programs that enhance individual motivation, according to engineers.

title: Supermassive black holes found in two tiny galaxies
description: Astronomers have found two ultra-compact dwarf galaxies with supermassive black holes, the second and third such galaxies found to harbor the objects. Together, the three examples suggest that black holes lurk at the center of most ultra-compact dwarfs, potentially doubling the number of supermassive black holes known in the universe. The tiny galaxies were likely leftovers of larger galaxies stripped of their outer layers after colliding into other, larger galaxies.

title: Newly discovered exoplanet may be best candidate in search for signs of life
description: An exoplanet orbiting a red dwarf star 40 light-years from Earth may be the new holder of the title 'best place to look for signs of life beyond the solar system.' Using ESO's HARPS instrument, and other telescopes, astronomers discovered a 'super-Earth' orbiting in the habitable zone around the star LHS 1140. This world is larger and more massive than the Earth and has likely retained most of its atmosphere. This makes it one of the most exciting targets for atmospheric studies.

Revealing the mystery behind the formation of hollowed nanoparticles during metal oxidation
description: New knowledge has been gained about the behavior of metal nanoparticles when they undergo oxidation, by integrating X-ray imaging and computer modeling and simulation. This knowledge adds to our understanding of fundamental processes like oxidation and corrosion.

title: Hubble's cosmic bubbles
description: Hubble has revealed a few of the tenuous threads comprising Sh2-308, a faint and wispy shell of gas located 5,200 light-years away in Canis Major.

title: Light rays from a supernova bent by the curvature of space-time around a galaxy
description: Astronomers have detected for the first time multiple images from a gravitationally lensed Type Ia supernova. The new observations suggest promising new avenues for the study of the accelerated expansion of the universe, gravity and distribution of dark matter in the universe.

title: Hubble celebrates 27 years with two close friends
description: This stunning cosmic pairing of the two very different looking spiral galaxies NGC 4302 and NGC 4298 was imaged by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope. The image brilliantly captures their warm stellar glow and brown, mottled patterns of dust.

title: Detailed map of potential Mars rover landing site
description: Mineral deposits in a region on Mars called Northeast Syrtis Major suggest a plethora of once-habitable environments. By mapping those deposits in the region's larger geological context, the research could help set the stage for a possible rover mission.

title: Astronomers perform largest-ever survey of high-mass binary star systems
description: 82 new high-mass binaries located in the Tarantula Nebula, also known as 30 Doradus, have been identified and characterized in the Large Magellanic Cloud, an international group of astronomers reports.

title: A new mineral from the oldest solar system solids in meteorites
description: Researchers have identified a new mineral in the oldest solar system solids from primitive meteorites. They've named it "rubinite" after Dr. Alan E. Rubin, a pioneering cosmochemist at University of California, Los Angeles. Rubinite was officially approved in March 2017 by the International Mineralogical Association.

title: Milky Way: Hydrogen halo lifts the veil of our galactic home
description: Astronomers have reported the first detections of diffuse hydrogen wafting about in a vast halo surrounding the Milky Way.

title: Mission control: Salty diet makes you hungry, not thirsty
description: We've all heard it: eating salty foods makes you thirstier. But what sounds like good nutritional advice turns out to be not true in the long run. In a study carried out during a simulated mission to Mars, an international group of scientists has found exactly the opposite to be true. 'Cosmonauts' who ate more salt retained more water, weren't as thirsty, and needed more energy.

title: NASA team explores using LISA Pathfinder as 'comet crumb' detector
description: Scientists hope to take advantage of LISA Pathfinder's record-breaking sensitivity to acceleration to map out the distribution of tiny dust particles shed by asteroids and comets far from Earth.

title: New insight into dark matter halos
description: Researchers used the Sloan Digital Sky Survey to find evidence that the dark matter halos surrounding galaxies and galaxy clusters have a discernible edge.

title: Wonder material? Novel nanotube structure strengthens thin films for flexible electronics
description: Reflecting the structure of composites found in nature and the ancient world, researchers have synthesized thin carbon nanotube (CNT) textiles that exhibit both high electrical conductivity and a level of toughness that is about fifty times higher than copper films, currently used in electronics.

title: 3D-printing of glass now possible
description: Three-dimensional printing allows extremely small and complex structures to be made even in small series. A new method now allows glass to be used for this technique. As a consequence of the properties of glass, such as transparency, thermal stability and resistance to acids, the use of this material in 3D-printing opens up manifold new applications in production and research, such as optics, data transmission, and biotechnology.

title: Circadian Rhythms Influence Treatment Effect
author: Jyoti Madhusoodanan
description: Across many diseases, taking medication at specific times of day may make the therapy more effective.

title: In experiments on Earth, testing possible building blocks of alien life
description: Extraterrestrial life, if it exists, could use different amino acid building blocks than living things here on Earth. To better understand what alien life might look like, researchers are studying which amino acids stand up to the types of extreme conditions found on other planets and moons.

author: Ed Silverman

author: Ed Silverman

title: Roche faces investigation into charges it wrongly thwarted rivals
author: Ed Silverman

author: Ed Silverman

author: Ed Silverman
